question.title: Can a method access the caller's local variable?
question.body:
I'd like my output to use singular nouns, when the reported quantity is one. Currently I keep doing things like:

logger.debug("Got {} row{}", rows, rows == 1 ? "" : 's');

but that gets tedious.

So, I'm thinking of a method, that would return the entire string "1 row" or "5 rows" depending on the value. The static String printable(int value, String name) is trivial to do, but tedious to use, it'd be invoked as printable(rows, "row"), which is redundant to anyone reading the code.

Perhaps, Java can do with just one argument? One of the:

  1. printable(rows) -- with the invoked method looking up the name of the variable passed to it in order to construct the noun (singular or plural depending on the value).
  2. printable("rows") -- with the invoked method looking up the value of the variable in the caller's scope (by the specified name)?

Something like this can be done with C preprocessor at compile-time, for example:

#define PRINTABLE(val) printable(val, #val)

Can Java do it (at runtime)?

Would be nice, if all of these could be skipped, if the current log-level is not verbose enough to actually output the log-entry anyway.
